title: Can self published books become bestsellers? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. I’ve done it twice. It’s not simple, mind you. But it’s definitely possible. The USA Today bestseller list is the easiest big list to hit. It requires somewhere between 6000 and 10,000 sales in a single week. You also need at least 500 of those sales to be somewhere other than Amazon, as they don’t list Amazon-only books. That’s the list my indie (self-published) books have hit twice. The NYT list is much harder. First, because you need to sell more books to hit that list (usually at LEAST 10k sales in one week), and second because the NYT curates their list and eliminates any ‘unworthy’ books. Generally, ‘unworthy’ to them means “published by someone who isn’t paying the NYT for advertising”. ;) It’s still possible for indies to hit this list, and some indie writers do every year, but it’s difficult. Of course, other types of ‘bestseller’ can be hit all the time. Anyone who wants to make the WSJ list can buy their way into it for about $10,000 most of the year. Would be guru-style speakers do this all the time, writing a book and then giving away thousands of copies of it to make the WSJ list, which then opens doors for paid speaking gigs. And I’ve had dozens of books make various Amazon ‘bestseller’ lists. Getting an Amazon orange bestseller tag isn’t that difficult at all.

No and it never will. People can’t buy books when they don’t even know about those books’ existance. That’s the reason why the ultimate challange for becoming a bestseller is DEFEATING the COMPETITION’S MARKETING. Now the problem in achieving this - for a selfpublished author - come from those factors: 1) big publishing companies are MANY. 2) they have budgets at disposal you can’t even imagine. 3) they have a level of experience in literary marketing you can’t even imagine. 4) they are at war with each other since the dawn of times, and that pushed their marketing expertise to the estreme. Compared to them, you are like a 14 years old, cannon fodder, military cook infantry soldier trying to with against a whole nation’s aviation, navy and tanks on your own. Are you ready to enter a ruthless war going on since the dawn of times, fought by thousands of people with more experience and means at disposal than you will ever have? Are you still sure you can win by ‘just writing something awsome’? I don’t think so.

I you mean New York Times bestseller or one of those, very unlikely. If you mean Amazon or Apple, very likely. The problem is, eBooks dont get given an ISBN. NYT and such collate sales based on ISBN reported sales. So if an eBook doesn’t have a best selling paperback version, thus providing an ISBN number, it will never be considered for NYT best seller because Amazon do not release sales information. But on Amazon, yes its possible. Any book in the top 150 of the paid store will also be #1 in most of it’s categories. And the sales necessary to get to this state are in the ballpark of what NYT requires to be #1 on it’s list. So in order to do both Amazon and NYT, you need to be releasing eBook and paperback at the same time, AND sell a huge number of them in the first week.

Not really a useful question. Sure, there are some small number of successes in the self-published field. There are lottery winners too, that doesn’t inform you on whether you will win the lottery. If you want to know if YOUR book will be successful, you need the judgement of someone who can read your book and give you advice. You also need to learn how to do marketing so you can connect your target audience with your book. Because all of the successes in self-publishing are also successes in marketing.

Sure. Have you heard of The Martian by Andy Weir? It started out as a self-published tome, with Weir releasing chapters on the net for review. Scientists began to weigh in on the plot, suggesting things and commenting on the accuracy of certain plot points. Weir took their advice and ended up with a superb story that was picked up by Random House and later became, as they say, a major motion picture. We should all be so lucky. Yes, potentially they can if you’re very good at marketing. It certainly won’t happen on its own without a lot of marketing effort. You shouldn’t expect that you can just put a book on Amazon and it will sell itself.

Of course it can. There are many success stories out there and they are growing by the day. Make sure it is written well, professionally edited, and aggressively marketed and you will put it in the best possible situation to become successful.
Theoretically this is possible. But as far as I know, it has never yet happened. (If I am incorrect here, please set me straight — thanks!)
“The Bridges of Madison County” by Robert James Waller started out as a self-published book. It was later picked up by a traditional publisher and was the basis for the movie by the same name.
